(of both caregivers and PwD), how reminiscence therapy is conducted, the creation and use of LSB, and the interest in multiple technological functionalities (personalization of stimuli, identification of the PwD emotional reactions to stimuli, and adaptation of current and future sessions).                 \u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                           A total of 661 participants from 39 countries worldwide answered the survey.     \t    Fifty-eight duplicate responses were removed.     \t         \t        \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Informal Caregivers       \t             \t    Ninety two percent of the respondents are female, younger than 60 y-o (74%), completed higher education (70%), have mild to moderate visual impairments (54%), are currently unemployed (43%), and are the children of the PwD (60%).             \tSixty-one percent live in the same house as the PwD.             \tThe assessment of perceived daily distress, daily distress caused by the PwD, and caregivers' work with the PwD reveals that they find themselves in distress and overburdened with the work (median of 4 in 5 for each).             \t\t             \tCaregivers' stress caused by PwD is statistically significantly different across different employment statuses ( RPLUS MATCH ).              \tPost-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference between caregivers with full-time jobs and those that are full-time caregivers (p=.002).             \tDaily distress perceived by the caregivers is statistically significantly different across different stages of the disease ( RPLUS MATCH ).              \tPost-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference between mild and severe stages (p=.002), with caregivers of PwD in a severe stage being more likely than those at mild stages to experience daily stress.             \t             \tThe amount of work with the PwD is also statistically significantly different across the different stages of the disease ( RPLUS MATCH ).              \tPost-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all the groups: mild vs moderate (p=.003), mild vs severe (p<.00001), and moderate vs severe (p<.00001).             \tPerceived daily distress, stress caused by the PwD, and caregivers' amount of work in the group of caregivers living with the PwD are statistically significantly higher than for the group that does not live with the PwD ( RPLUS MATCH ;  RPLUS MATCH ;  RPLUS MATCH ).         \t\t         \t    The majority of caregivers are familiar with technology: they use smartphones daily, and computers/tablet/iPad five to six days a week.         \t                    \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 PwD                                Sixty seven percent are female, older than 70 y-o (89%), and have completed at least high school education (67%).             \tThey have mainly mild to moderate visual impairments, such as cataracts, hyperopia, and myopia (61%).             \tThey attend multiple medical specialties, such as neurology (51%), psychiatry (20%), psychology (and neuropsychology) (13%), among others.             \tCaregivers indicate that the PwD have a clinical diagnosis of Alzheimer's (47%), diagnosed for over three years (54%), and are at a perceived moderate stage of the disease (48%).             \t                 \tThey live mainly at a family home (85%) with at least one person living with the PwD (83%).             \tThe assessment of the level of independence of the PwD for different types of activities reveals that they: a) do not cook independently; b) are able to perform activities of daily living but with some help (e.g., dressing); c) are able to move from short to long distances only with the help of third parties; and d) perform some entertainment activities only with the help of third parties (e.g., watching television).                         \u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Sixty-five percent of the PwD are performing reminiscence therapy, while 23% stopped doing it due to increased detachment of the PwD (66%), lack of perceived usefulness or PwD inability to attend sessions (25%), lack of material (10%), and lack of time (7%).      \t\tThe remaining ones (12%) never performed reminiscence therapy, as it was prevented by detachment of the PwD (66%), lack of perceived usefulness or PwD not being able to participate (25%), lack of time (8%), and lack of materials (7%).      \t\tWe analyzed whether performing (or not) reminiscence therapy was associated with the overall daily stress, daily stress and daily work due to the PwD, employment, age, and education of caregivers, as well as the age, education and stage of the disease of the PwD.     \t\tThere were no significant relationship for all variables except for caregiver's daily work, PwD's level of education, and disease's stage.     \t\t     \t\t     \t\tThe daily amount of work of the caregiver due to the PwD is {"position": null, "sentence": "F.) acted as an independent referee in case of divergence.  \u00a7 SURVEY 1               In this section, we present our results regarding the sample characteristics (of both caregivers and PwD), how reminiscence therapy is conducted, the creation and use of LSB, and the interest in multiple technological functionalities (personalization of stimuli, identification of the PwD emotional reactions to stimuli, and adaptation of current and future sessions).                 \u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                           A total of 661 participants from 39 countries worldwide answered the survey.     \t    Fifty-eight duplicate responses were removed.     \t         \t        \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Informal Caregivers       \t             \t    Ninety two percent of the respondents are female, younger than 60 y-o (74%), completed higher education (70%), have mild to moderate visual impairments (54%), are currently unemployed (43%), and are the children of the PwD (60%).             \tSixty-one percent live in the same house as the PwD.             \tThe assessment of perceived daily distress, daily distress caused by the PwD, and caregivers' work with the PwD reveals that they find themselves in distress and overburdened with the work (median of 4 in 5 for each).             \t\t             \tCaregivers' stress caused by PwD is statistically significantly different across different employment statuses ( RPLUS MATCH ).              \tPost-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference between caregivers with full-time jobs and those that are full-time caregivers (p=.002).             \tDaily distress perceived by the caregivers is statistically significantly different across different stages of the disease ( RPLUS MATCH ).              \tPost-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference between mild and severe stages (p=.002), with caregivers of PwD in a severe stage being more likely than those at mild stages to experience daily stress.             \t             \tThe amount of work with the PwD is also statistically significantly different across the different stages of the disease ( RPLUS MATCH ).              \tPost-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all the groups: mild vs moderate (p=.003), mild vs severe (p<.00001), and moderate vs severe (p<.00001).             \tPerceived daily distress, stress caused by the PwD, and caregivers' amount of work in the group of caregivers living with the PwD are statistically significantly higher than for the group that does not live with the PwD ( RPLUS MATCH ;  RPLUS MATCH ;  RPLUS MATCH ).         \t\t         \t    The majority of caregivers are familiar with technology: they use smartphones daily, and computers/tablet/iPad five to six days a week.         \t                    \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 PwD                                Sixty seven percent are female, older than 70 y-o (89%), and have completed at least high school education (67%).             \tThey have mainly mild to moderate visual impairments, such as cataracts, hyperopia, and myopia (61%).             \tThey attend multiple medical specialties, such as neurology (51%), psychiatry (20%), psychology (and neuropsychology) (13%), among others.             \tCaregivers indicate that the PwD have a clinical diagnosis of Alzheimer's (47%), diagnosed for over three years (54%), and are at a perceived moderate stage of the disease (48%).             \t                 \tThey live mainly at a family home (85%) with at least one person living with the PwD (83%).             \tThe assessment of the level of independence of the PwD for different types of activities reveals that they: a) do not cook independently; b) are able to perform activities of daily living but with some help (e.g., dressing); c) are able to move from short to long distances only with the help of third parties; and d) perform some entertainment activities only with the help of third parties (e.g., watching television).                         \u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Sixty-five percent of the PwD are performing reminiscence therapy, while 23% stopped doing it due to increased detachment of the PwD (66%), lack of perceived usefulness or PwD inability to attend sessions (25%), lack of material (10%), and lack of time (7%).      \t\tThe remaining ones (12%) never performed reminiscence therapy, as it was prevented by detachment of the PwD (66%), lack of perceived usefulness or PwD not being able to participate (25%), lack of time (8%), and lack of materials (7%).      \t\tWe analyzed whether performing (or not) reminiscence therapy was associated with the overall daily stress, daily stress and daily work due to the PwD, employment, age, and education of caregivers, as well as the age, education and stage of the disease of the PwD.     \t\tThere were no significant relationship for all variables except for caregiver's daily work, PwD's level of education, and disease's stage.     \t\t     \t\t     \t\tThe daily amount of work of the caregiver due to the PwD is statistically significantly different across those that perform (or not) the reminiscence therapy ( RPLUS MATCH ).      \t\tPost-hoc analysis revealed, as expected, that when the amount of daily work with the patient is higher, therapy is performed less often.     \t\tPerforming reminiscence therapy with a moderate amount of daily work with the PwD is significantly more than expected, while those performing therapy with a higher daily work is significantly less than expected.     \t\tFor those that reported a low or moderate amount of work (levels 1 to 3), 67% currently apply reminiscence therapy, 19% already did but stopped, and 14% never did.     \t\tWhen considering a higher amount of work (levels 4 and 5), the ones performing therapy reduced to 57%, while the ones that stopped performing therapy increased to 29%.     \t     \t\t     \t\tThere were a statistically significant relation between performing therapy and the stage of the disease of the PwD ( RPLUS MATCH ).     \t\tPost-hoc analysis suggests that PwD in initial stages of the disease perform therapy often: mild (81%), moderate (74.9%), and severe (47.1%).     \t\tAs the disease progresses, there is an increase in the number of PwD who stop performing therapy: mild (7.1%), moderate (16.3%), and severe (37.1%).     \t\t     \t\tThose performing reminiscence therapy with a moderate stage of dementia are statistically significantly more than expected, while those in a severe stage are statistically significantly less than expected.     \t\tFor those that already performed therapy and the PwD has a moderate stage of dementia are statistically significantly less than expected, while those in a severe stage are statistically significantly more.     \t    There were also a statistically significant relation between performing therapy and the education level of the PwD ( RPLUS MATCH ).     \t\tPost-hoc analysis suggests that those that never performed reminiscence therapy and have a high school degree are significantly more than expected, while the ones with a middle school degree are significantly less.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Session\u2019s Characterization                       For our analysis, we considered answers from caregivers that were performing therapy and those who already performed.     \t\tSessions mainly occur at the home of PwD or relatives (92%) with the attendance of the caregiver (62%) and relatives (62%) besides the PwD, a sessions' frequency per month of either more than 10 times (44%) or 1-2 times (23%), and an average session duration of less than 30 minutes (66%).     \t\tWhen reviewing the past, one can expect that some communication between the PwD and remaining participants takes place.     \t\tIn fact, it occurs: in some cases (38%), a lot (32%), and little (23%).          \t\tIn the course of each session, different multimedia could be used to elicit memories: image, music, video, or combinations among those.     \t\tCaregivers use as stimuli mainly images (55%) or music (37%), and only 18% uses videos; they are usually personal, i.e., multimedia that is related to the PwD and their life: images (88%), videos (73%), and songs (63%).     \t\t     \t\tImages are provided by relatives (81%), the PwD itself (44%), and friends (12%).      \t\tThey are mainly available as printed pictures in physical albums (96%), but they are also stored in the smartphone/tablet gallery (41%), or in the computer (27%).     \t\tMusic is provided by relatives (66%), Internet through music streaming services (46%), and the PwD (32%).     \t\tSongs are usually stored in tapes/CD (57%), streaming services on the Internet (48%), and the computer, smartphone or tablet (45%).     \t\tVideos are provided by relatives (83%), PwD (24%), and friends (21%).     \t\tThey are stored in the computer, smartphone or tablet (71%), and tapes/DVD (43%).      \t\t             \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 PwD Emotional Reactions          \t             When reviewing our memories, it is common to have different emotional reactions - either positive or negative - depending on the memory in question. \t\t\tRegarding the emotional reactions that occur during sessions, caregivers reported that they either perceive what the PwD is feeling (62%) or the PwD is able to describe what he/she is feeling (46%). \t\t\tConsidering the different multimedia used within sessions, images (66%) and music (55%) lead to some kind of positive reaction (e.g., enthusiasm, joy, etc.) from PwD. \t\t\tNegative emotional reactions occurs during sessions (64%). \t\t\t \t\t\tThe main situations in which PwD experience negative emotions are: i) related to cognitive-impairments (58%) - not being able to remember something (e.g., when the memories do not line up with the reality), confusion (e.g., PwD is able to recognize a person in the image but not being able to recall his/her name), and the inability to express what he/she is feeling; ii) autobiographical memories (44%) - remembering (or seeing pictures of) loved ones that have passed away, and bad memories from their lives (e.g., abusive parents or spouse, or a divorce). \t\t\tWhile experiencing negative emotions, PwD's have multiple reactions: behavioral, i.e., getting agitated, aggressive, detached, and anxious (56%), verbal (49%), and emotional, mainly through crying (47%). \t\t\tFollowing, we present some quotes of the informal caregivers that exemplify each of the situations reported.                                                In order to cope with the negative emotional reactions, caregivers adopt different strategies: \t\t    verbal actions toward the PwD (67%), change environment/theme/activity (50.00%), and non-verbal actions toward the PwD (21%). \t\t    We can see in the following quotes that caregivers usually talk with the PwD, trying to calm them down by rationalizing and validating what the PwD are feeling, as well as helping them deal with the triggered memories.  \t\t    However, sometimes, they opt to avoid continuing to talk about specific themes to not worsen the PwD's (or they own) emotional state.                                                \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Life Story Book                       LSB are frequently used as a reminiscence tool to support recollecting autobiographical memories <cit.>. \t\t    They are the result of a life review process performed by the PwD with the support of staff and family members to build a personal biography that acts as a bridge to the past and a connection to the present. \t\t    It can be a very time-consuming task since it may require help from third parties to collect the information, which may not always be feasible or practical. \t\t     \t\t    Only 23% of the caregivers have currently a LSB of the PwD, but the majority of the remaining ones are interested in having one (80%). \t\t    Although we have not collected data to directly answer why most caregivers do not have an LSB of the PwD, as we can see in the following quotes, our open-end questions allow us to hypothesise that it is due to the amount of work (and stress) caregivers already have in their daily live. \t\t     \t\t     \t\t     \t\t    Considering those that already have the LSB or are interested in having one, they mainly prefer to store it the old fashioned way, i.e., physically, such as an album of photos (82%). \t\t    Eighty-two percent of caregivers had (or want) to have help in the process of creating the LSB, and usually they spend (or are willing to spent) up to 10 hours in this process (60%). \t\t    The information is obtained in-person (81%), by e-mail (24%), and through social networks (23%). \t\t    Finally, caregivers indicate that relatives (91%), PwD (62%), friends (57%), and the caregivers themselves (49%) should have access to the LSB.                     \u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities               Caregivers are very interested in all the technological functionalities (median of 4 in 5 for each) that may help to revisit older memories from their loved ones or to create an LSB, namely: i) automatically retrieving new images; ii) retrieving life-based images (of the PwD), iii) retrieving interest-based images (e.g., favorite artist, hobbies); iv) adapting current session (based on a negative emotional reaction to an image); v) adapting future sessions (based on the negative emotional reactions that occurred).         \t                                           We further analyzed if the interest in any of the functionalities is associated with currently performing (or  not) the reminiscence therapy, already having a LSB or interest in having one, and finally, the overall daily stress, daily stress and daily work due to the PwD.                                           \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Automatically retrieving new images                      The interest in creating LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality ( RPLUS MATCH ).
